analysis.weekly_summary:
This week's carnivore content reveals a significant split in the data collection - the top channel 'The Plant Slant' (1.1M views) is actually a plant-based/anti-carnivore creator, creating confusion in the dataset. Among actual carnivore creators, the focus is heavily on New Year preparation and beginner guidance, with both Dr. Anthony Chaffee and Steak and Butter Gal releasing 'If I Started Carnivore in 2026' content. The community shows strong engagement around practical concerns: nutrient completeness (especially B vitamins), oxalate dumping symptoms, travel logistics, and recipe innovations for those seeking variety while staying carnivore.

A notable trend is the emphasis on troubleshooting common failures - Max German's video on mistakes and Courtney Luna's discussion of weight loss stalls generated significant discussion. The community continues to share dramatic health transformations, particularly from former vegetarians/vegans, with multiple testimonials about reversing MS symptoms, IBS, and other chronic conditions. Recipe content remains popular, especially carnivore versions of comfort foods (pancakes, ice cream, kebabs) as creators help followers maintain the diet long-term through the holiday season and into 2026 resolutions.

trending_topics.description: Multiple creators releasing comprehensive guides for starting or restarting carnivore in the new year, focusing on avoiding common mistakes and setting up for success
Discussion about whether beef-only carnivore provides adequate B1, with emphasis on pork as the best animal source and addressing nutrient completeness fears
Community members reporting challenging detox symptoms when transitioning from plant-based diets, including crystals in eyes, migraines, and energy fluctuations
Addressing the controversial topic of why some people don't lose weight on carnivore, with discussion of calories, fat ratios, and metabolic healing timeframes
Surge in recipe content for carnivore versions of traditional favorites (pancakes, ice cream, kebabs, cakes) to help with long-term adherence

Weight loss stalls on carnivore remain controversial, with tension between 'eat to satiety, never count calories' purists and those acknowledging that some people need calorie awareness or have metabolic damage requiring patience

Recipe content serves a crucial retention function - creators recognize that long-term adherence requires addressing psychological food needs, not just nutritional ones. Carnivore versions of comfort foods help people stay compliant

The community shows strong skepticism toward mainstream medical advice, with recurring themes of medical gaslighting, failed plant-based recommendations from doctors, and self-directed healing journeys

Travel and social logistics remain a practical barrier, with creators offering tactical advice (packing coolers on flights, seeking Five Guys/Chipotle, explaining diet to family) to help followers maintain the diet in real-world situations

qa_section.question: Why am I not losing weight on carnivore despite eating only meat?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! I totally get how frustrating weight loss plateaus can feel. When it comes to the carnivore diet and weight loss, the science gets pretty nuanced. Research suggests that simply eliminating carbs doesn't guarantee weight loss - calorie balance is still king. My Oura ring data and blood glucose tracking have shown me how individual metabolic responses can be.

    A 2020 study in Nutrients highlighted that while high-protein, low-carb diets can trigger metabolic advantages, total caloric intake matters most. If you're consuming more calories from meat than you're burning, weight loss stalls. Factors like insulin sensitivity, stress levels (tracked beautifully on my WHOOP), sleep quality, and individual metabolic differences play huge roles.

    For sustainable weight transformation, I recommend tracking not just calories but macronutrient ratios, stress markers, and recovery metrics. Consider working with a metabolic specialist who can do detailed blood panel analysis to understand your unique biochemistry. Your body is telling a complex story - we just need to listen carefully.

qa_section.question: Is beef-only carnivore nutritionally complete, especially for B vitamins?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When it comes to a beef-only carnivore diet and nutritional completeness, the science gets pretty nuanced. Research suggests beef is an incredibly nutrient-dense food, especially for B vitamins like B12, but total nutritional completeness is more complicated.

Beef provides exceptional levels of bioavailable vitamin B12, zinc, and high-quality protein. A 2022 nutrition review in the Journal of Nutritional Science showed grass-fed beef contains significantly higher micronutrient density compared to grain-fed varieties. However, a pure beef-only approach might create potential deficiencies in vitamin C, folate, and certain trace minerals that typically come from plant sources.

My recommendation? If you're exploring a carnivore approach, consider liver as a 'superfood' complement to muscle meat. Beef liver dramatically increases micronutrient profiles and provides a more comprehensive nutritional spectrum. I've seen clients using continuous glucose monitors (like my beloved Levels app) track incredible metabolic responses when integrating organ meats strategically.

qa_section.question: What are these detox symptoms I'm experiencing (oxalate dumping)?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When diving into significant dietary shifts like a carnivore approach, your body can definitely experience some interesting transitions. 'Oxalate dumping' is a fascinating phenomenon where individuals switching to high-protein, low-oxalate diets might experience temporary symptoms like skin irritation, fatigue, or mild digestive changes.

Research suggests this isn't a formally recognized medical condition, but a reported experience among people radically changing their nutritional intake. From my tracking with continuous glucose monitors and blood panels, I've seen fascinating metabolic adaptations during dietary transitions. Symptoms can include temporary inflammation, potential mineral rebalancing, and your body's metabolic 'recalibration.'

The key is gentle, mindful transitions. I always recommend tracking your biomarkers through tools like HealthKit or Oura Ring to understand your individual response. Blood tests tracking inflammation markers, kidney function, and nutrient levels can provide incredible insights into how your body is adapting.

qa_section.question: How do I travel while maintaining carnivore diet?
qa_section.answer:
Okay, carnivore travelers - let's get real about keeping your protein game strong while globetrotting! üçñ‚úàÔ∏è First pro tip: Always pack portable protein sources like beef jerky, canned fish, and protein powder. Research shows maintaining protein intake during travel helps preserve muscle mass and metabolic flexibility.

The key strategy is planning ahead. Many airport lounges and international restaurants now offer protein-friendly options like grilled meats, eggs, and seafood. Pro YouTubers like Mike Mutzel and Paul Saladino have totally cracked the code on traveling carnivore. I've seen their travel meal prep videos, and they're legit game-changers.

Quick hack: Use apps like Google Maps and Happy Cow to scout protein-friendly restaurants in advance. Some travelers even pre-pack a small travel cooler with vacuum-sealed meats. Just check international customs regulations first - you don't want your premium grass-fed ribeye getting confiscated! üòÇ

qa_section.question: Should I include organs/pork/dairy or stick to beef only?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! I totally get why you're exploring the carnivore diet's nuances. From my research tracking metabolic markers and protein intake, diversifying animal protein sources can actually optimize your nutritional profile.

Beef is phenomenal, but organs like liver provide critical micronutrients that muscle meat alone can't deliver. Specifically, beef liver is a nutritional powerhouse with vitamin A, B12, and iron in highly bioavailable forms. Regarding dairy and pork, individual metabolic responses vary. My recommendation? Start with grass-fed beef, slowly introduce organ meats like liver and heart, and track your blood glucose and energy markers using tools like Oura Ring or continuous glucose monitors.

Research suggests that nutrient density matters more than strict protein source limitations. The key is quality, sourcing, and how YOUR unique body responds. Blood work and subjective energy tracking will be your best indicators of dietary success.

qa_section.caveats: Individual metabolic responses vary. Not a one-size-fits-all approach. Recommend consulting healthcare professionals and regular blood work monitoring.

qa_section.question: How long does the adaptation period take before feeling benefits?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When diving into the carnivore diet adaptation, most individuals report significant metabolic shifts between 4-12 weeks. Research suggests the body requires substantial time to fully transition metabolic pathways from glucose to primarily fat and protein metabolism.

My clients using continuous glucose monitors (like the ones I track with Levels and Oura) typically see metabolic stabilization around 6-8 weeks. During this period, you might experience temporary fatigue, electrolyte fluctuations, and potential digestive recalibration. Your body is essentially rewiring its energy extraction mechanisms from carbohydrate-dependent to protein and fat-driven systems.

Interestingly, individual adaptation varies dramatically based on prior metabolic flexibility, current health status, and genetic factors. I always recommend tracking key biomarkers like fasting insulin, inflammation markers (hsCRP), and comprehensive metabolic panels to understand your unique physiological response.

qa_section.question: Is counting calories necessary on carnivore or just eat to satiety?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! I know navigating nutritional approaches can feel overwhelming, especially with something as focused as the carnivore diet. Current research suggests that for most people on a carnivore diet, eating to satiety might actually be more effective than strict calorie counting.

A fascinating study from 2020 in the Journal of Clinical Medicine found that high-protein, low-carb diets naturally regulate hunger hormones like leptin and ghrelin. This means your body's innate signals might do a better job of managing intake than manually tracking every calorie. My Whoop and Oura data tracking with clients shows fascinating metabolic responses - many report spontaneous calorie reduction when protein intake is high and consistent.

However, individual metabolic variability is real. While some thrive on pure satiety signaling, others might need more precise tracking. I recommend starting with intuitive eating and tracking key biomarkers like blood glucose, weight, and energy levels. Your body is an incredible feedback system if you learn to listen.

qa_section.question: What about eating carnivore when spouse/family isn't on board?
qa_section.answer:
Okay, let's get real about navigating the carnivore diet when your family's giving you major side-eye üëÄ Research actually shows dietary differences can create legit relationship tension, especially around meal planning and social eating.

Most couples I'm seeing in the health community are solving this through compromise and communication. Pro tip: Don't turn dinner into a battleground. Instead, focus on preparing shared meals where you can customize your protein portions. YouTube creators like Dr. Ken Berry have amazing content about making mixed dietary households work smoothly.

Nutritional science suggests gradual transitions work best. Consider introducing your family to some carnivore-adjacent recipes that everyone might enjoy. Think high-protein meals with flexible sides. The key is making your dietary choice feel collaborative, not confrontational.

top_comments.text:
For boiling:
‚Ä¢ 2 cups dry green or brown lentils
‚Ä¢ 1 large potato peeled
‚Ä¢ 1 onion peeled
2 whole carrots peeled
water to cover
‚Ä¢ Salt to taste
For the mixture:
‚Ä¢ 1 cup breadcrumbs (Add more if needed)
‚Ä¢ 1 cup chopped fresh parsley
1-2 tsp paprika
‚Ä¢ 1 tsp ground cumin
Salt and pepper to taste
Optional: chili flakes

For frying:
‚Ä¢ Oil for shallow frying
For serving:
Turkish-style bread rolls or Pita
Yogurt-based sauce like Tzatziki
‚Ä¢ Tomato slices
‚Ä¢ Onion slices mixed with parsley and sumac
‚Ä¢ Grilled long green peppers (optional)
Pickles (optional)

Instructions
Cook the lentils and vegetables:
Add the lentils to a large pot. Place the whole potato, onion, and carrots on top.
Cover with water, season lightly with salt, and cook until everything is soft (about 25-30 minutes).

2
Mash everything:
Drain excess water if there is any. Mash the lentils, carrots, onion, and potato together in the pot until mostly smooth but still a little chunky.
3
Make the mixture:
Transfer the mash to a bowl. Add breadcrumbs, chopped parsley, paprika, cumin, salt, pepper, and chili flakes (optional). Mix until the mixture holds together. Add more breadcrumbs if needed.

4
Shape patties:
Form oval or square patties by pressing the mixture firmly with your hands.
5
Fry:
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Fry patties on both sides until golden brown and crispy.

Assemble sandwiches:
Slice the bread, add the sauce, tomato slices, onion-parsley mix, 3-4 lentil patties, and grilled green pepper. Press lightly and enjoy warm!

top_comments.text: A lot of legume (Beans and lentils)  patties  are great for making in large batches and freeze for quick reheated meals. For those who are thinking of trying that with this or any other recipe, do it first with a small batch and lay them out in a single layer on something easy to take in and out of the freezer. Getting the surface of them frozen makes them less likely to stick together once they are in a container. Worst case scenario is that the recipe does not lend itself well to freezing and the patties crumble. you can than use those crumbly bits as a browned ground meat substitute in a lot of other dishes so nothing goes to waste.

top_comments.text:
Meat is digested in the stomach with strong acid, while plants are fermented in the gut.

If you only eat plants, you don‚Äôt need high stomach acid, so your body stops making it. This becomes a problem if you start eating meat again because you won‚Äôt have enough acid to digest it. The fix is to gradually increase meat consumption so your stomach acid production ramps up again.

You also need bile to digest animal fats. If you‚Äôre not eating fat, your bile flow slows, bile thickens into sludge and gallstones can form. When you suddenly reintroduce fat, you may not digest it well because your bile ducts can be blocked. To get bile flowing again, bile salts and gradually increasing animal fat can help.

Bile is released from the gallbladder when you eat fat and it‚Äôs not just for fat digestion. Bile salts also act as a natural intestinal lubricant and mild laxative, keeping stool soft and triggering the muscular contractions that move waste along. Low bile output makes stool drier, harder and slower to pass.

If you‚Äôre sensitive to histamine, source non-hung/aged meat straight from a slaughterhouse.

A plant-based, low-animal-fat diet is not good for long-term health, despite what‚Äôs promoted. Humans are designed to eat meat and animal fats.  Things start breaking down when we don‚Äôt.

top_comments.text: As a 4-month carnivore I feel the need to tell you my personal trick. The thing I hated the most is the mess on my stove from cooking in a pan. About two months ago I switched to the air fryer. I put the steak in the air fryer, put some bacon drippings over the top of each steak (luckily my local butcher makes his own bacon and sells the bacon drippings), salt on top and then cook it to my liking. It goes on the plate and then I pour the dripping from the air fryer over the top on my meat like a sauce and it is delicious. Easy clean up and no messy stove. Just enjoying sharing what works for me. Cheers from Australia.

top_comments.text:
6 years carnivore December 12th 2025. What i wish i knew when i started was how important salt is on a low carb/zero carb/carnivore lifestyle. And i started because i felt like my lifelong epilepsy was killing me slowly. Nothing was working, and after seeing a dr and her telling me i needed antidepressants, i realised i wasn't going to get any help from my dr and i'd have to figure my health out for myself. After some research i came upon carnivore and it changed my life. I came from a standard western diet (uk) from childhood to teen, then to a bodybuilders diet through my mid 20s to thirties - which i would call plant based and low fat - and is where i felt my absolute worst, and then carnivore from age 40. I'm 46 now. And like i said earlier. Carnivore changed my life!!
But i didn't know that salt would be so important and possibly the reason why i developed epilepsy in the first place. My mum told me she never used salt in her cooking - and still doesn't (and she's always suffering somethingü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è) i had absences when i was a child and full blown seizures after i started my periods. When i think back to my past, i don't remember much because i was always sick. I never felt well within myself. And so when i dig deeper into this carnivore diet, different branches of information lead back to how i felt as a youngster and lightbulbs are going off!! Could a lack of salt have caused this? Why do i have seizures on my period mostly, and why does salt always make me feel better straight away? I never added it all together until nearly 6 years in because i thought stopping the seizures was all about the fat - and it wasn't! At least for me! High fat carnivore drastically reduced the seizures to almost nothing but adding/supplementing salt - was the cherry on top! The bow that tied it all together! This has blown my mind! And salt isn't just important for me and my epilepsy, its important for human health overall and i believe everybody should be using it daily. Dr Chaffee... i tell ya, if i knew this when i started... life changing. Meat, fat and plenty of salt guys. This is all we need.
top_comments.author: @No_Frills_Carnivore

top_comments.text: I agree 100%, Ive been carnivore for 3 years, I healed amazingly with fairly strict carnivore, adding in some experimentation, to see how I reacted to dairy, seasonings, etc. I watched your videos, and am very happy I chose to jump right in, a go strict, especially for the first year!

top_comments.text: Thank you, Dr. Chaffee. I will be into my third year eating carnivore in early 2026. It has helped me in many ways. I've lost a lot of weight, am no longer diabetic, no longer have the muscle/nerve pain issues that I had, and overall am thriving. I never thought that would be possible at my advanced age. I appreciate you and your videos and the way you explain why eating carnivore actually works and heals.

top_comments.text:
Thanks Dr. Chaffee for the reminder about ammonia from protein breakdown.
When I first went keto (full carnivore now), I had a strong ammonia smell on my body for a few months. Really concerning at the time and I couldn't find any information about it. Eventually it just disappeared.
After hearing you mention this, I searched again and it's well-documented now. It's caused by excess protein breakdown during adaptation. Your body produces ammonia as a byproduct, and during transition it gets released through sweat and breath.
Good news: it's temporary and normal. Typically resolves within weeks to months once you're fat-adapted.
If anyone else is experiencing this, don't panic. Stay hydrated, keep electrolytes balanced (especially potassium), and eat enough fat relative to protein. Your body is just adapting.
Hope this helps someone going through it right now.
top_comments.author: @iambrew

videos.title: Easiest Kebab Recipe Ever
videos.description:
Comment BEEFY if you‚Äôd love to try this!

Follow me for more delicious Ôøºand easy carnivore tips and recipes!

top_comments.text:
Meat Kebab Recipe

Ingredients:
-2 LBs 85/15 ground beef
-1 Large onion, grated
-3 garlic cloves
-1/4 cup whole milk greek yogurt
-2 tsp Cumin
-1 tsp Paprika
-1 tsp Oregano
-1 tsp Salt
-1/2 tsp Black pepper

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 400 F
2. Add all ingredients into a large bowl, mix well.
3. Divide in to 4 equal portions.
4. Place one portion into center of parchment paper (12x16).
5. Place another paper same size on top.
6. Use rolling pin/hands to roll mix into thin rectangle.
7. Starting from long side, fold parchment over meat
8. Roll tightly until forms flat compact log. Repeat.
9. Bake 400 F for 15 mins.
10. Let cool just enough to handle, unroll.
11. Break into slices or small chunks, return to baking sheet.
12. Broil for 2-3 mins (lightly golden / crisp).

videos.title: Fluffy carnivore cake recipe
videos.description:
Comment ‚ÄúCAKE‚Äù for the recipe to this delicious carnivore cake

Comment ‚ÄúCAKE‚Äù if you would love to try this 100% carnivore fluffy cake recipe!

This is truly the perfect base to any cake you could possibly want to make! I‚Äôve made this as a birthday cream cake for my brother‚Äôs birthday, a low carb strawberry shortcake so many times, even turned it into fluffy cookies! 
Every time I make this cake, my family says ‚Äúits the best tasting healthy cake they‚Äôve ever eaten‚Äù üòÜShoutout to Kelly for creating this. @kelly_hogan91 
 
Recipe:
-separate 8 egg yolks from the whites
-in one bowl, mix well the 8 yolks with 8 oz cream cheese 
-in another bowl, beat whites until they become as stiff as possible
-slowly and gently pour and fold the yolk mix into bowl of whites
-bake cake(s) in baking sheet at 300 Fahrenheit for 25 min
-apply whipped heavy whipping cream or any frosting you like all over cake
-you can customize this basic recipe to add whatever ingredients you‚Äôd like!

top_comments.text:
Beef (especially certain cuts)
Yes, beef absolutely contains thiamine‚Äîjust not as concentrated as pork.
Ground beef (especially 70/30 or 75/25)
‚Ä¢ ~0.05‚Äì0.07 mg B1 per 100 g
‚Ä¢ Adds up quickly if beef is your staple
Chuck, round, brisket
‚Ä¢ Similar thiamine content
Eating 1.5‚Äì2 lb of beef/day provides a meaningful baseline intake
 Beef alone can cover a substantial portion of B1 needs, especially in low-carb metabolism where thiamine demand is lower.
2. Ruminant Organs (this is where people forget)
If ancient Yisrael did anything right nutritionally, it was nose-to-tail.
Liver (beef or lamb)
‚Ä¢ ~0.1‚Äì0.2 mg B1 per 100 g
‚Ä¢ Also supplies magnesium and other B vitamins that work with thiamine
Heart
‚Ä¢ Comparable or slightly higher B1 than liver
Kidney
‚Ä¢ Often overlooked, but legit source
üëâ Even 1‚Äì2 small servings per week materially improves thiamine status.
3. Fish with Scales and Fins (Leviticus 11‚Äìclean)
This is a big one people ignore.
Tuna
Salmon
Mackerel
Sardines
Thiamine content varies, but:
~0.05‚Äì0.1 mg B1 per 100 g
Sardines punch above their weight nutritionally
‚ö†Ô∏è One note of precision: raw fish contains thiaminase, which destroys B1.
‚û°Ô∏è Cooking deactivates thiaminase, so cooked fish = no problem.
4. Eggs (supportive, not primary)
Eggs won‚Äôt carry the whole load, but they contribute.
~0.03 mg B1 per large egg
Also supply sulfur, choline, and B2, which support energy metabolism
Think of eggs as backup singers, not the lead guitar.
5. Dairy (if tolerated)
Not huge, but not zero.
Raw or full-fat milk
Hard cheeses
Low thiamine density, but:
Adds calories without carb load
Supports overall B-vitamin balance
Why pork looks ‚Äúspecial‚Äù (but isn‚Äôt necessary)
Pork is high in thiamine per gram, yes. That‚Äôs why Berry harps on it.
But here‚Äôs the part people gloss over:
Thiamine deficiency risk skyrockets with high carbohydrate intake
On low-carb / carnivore, B1 requirements drop
Ruminant meat + organs + fish easily cover needs
Ancient Yisrael didn‚Äôt need pigs to function. Neither do you.

 Beef (especially fatty ground)
 Ruminant organs
 Clean fish (cooked)
 Eggs
 Optional dairy
All Leviticus 11‚Äìcompliant. All carnivore-compatible. All sufficient for vitamin B1.

videos.title: Carnivore pancake recipe! #carnivorediet #carnivorerecipes #ketodiet #ketorecipes #ketopancakes

top_comments.text:
CARNIVORE PANCAKE RECIPE:

3 eggs separated
2.5 tbsp collagen (I use @equipfoods brand vanilla, you can also use unflavored if you're strict, the flavored has stevia. Code Luna to save 20% off)
1 tbsp beef gelatin (brand NuNaturals unflavored off Amazon)

Whip egg whites until stiff peaks form, about 3 minutes and add gelatin while blending.
Blend the yolks with the collagen.
Fold white mixture into yolk mixture.
Pan fry for about 5 minutes on each side using medium-low heat, cover with lid or parchment paper. Enjoy!

Recipe from Maria Emmerich ‚ù§

videos.description:
You‚Äôre eating carnivore.

So why isn‚Äôt the scale moving?

In this episode, Courtney sits down with @DaniConwayOfficial, functional nutrition practitioner who lost 65 pounds after discovering why dieting harder was actually making things worse.

We break down the real reasons carnivore (and keto) stop working, especially for women ‚Äî including the metabolic mistakes almost no one is talking about.

You‚Äôll learn:

Why ‚Äúeat less, move more‚Äù backfires (especially over 40)

The hidden role of insulin resistance & leptin dysfunction

High-protein vs high-fat: what actually matters

Why cheat meals may be slowing fat loss

The truth about GLP-1s, reverse dieting, and metabolic repair

Why testing beats guessing ‚Äî every time

If you‚Äôre tired of restarting, restricting, and wondering what‚Äôs wrong with you ‚Äî this conversation may be the missing piece.

üëâ Follow for real-food, carnivore-forward health without the diet drama.

top_comments.text:
Only thing that works for me is dry fasting. And recently, 3 day fasting mimicking sardine fast - that‚Äôs 1 can sardine per 50lbs body weight & 2.5 for me, a day and NOT the all you can eat sardine regimen - followed by 3 day DRY fast. Awesome plus healing a difficult tendonopathy, like nothing else. The actual real fast is way easy even on first day after the ketogenic set up of the sardine fast mimicking days.

Luckily for me, I have a European palette so sardines, funky salty fishy foods, liver, organs, collagenous chewy parts of animal, raw meat, raw eggs - all are delicious to me. I also ferment local, seasonal fruit often home-grown, and eat little bits, mostly drinking the ferment water. As well as fermenting raw milk kefir.

Im post-meno so fasting is not a hindrance of anything for me. I get bloaty and farty on water fasting and anything, even after almost 3 years carnivore. Been fasting and IF a long time. Thyroid fine. Hair thick and fast growing. Sleep great. Emergy great. (Getting ahead of the carb freaks. üòÇ) EVERYONE IS DIFFERENT. As a 5 foot tall muscular busty woman, nobody else‚Äôs protocols work for me except my own, honed and experimented and re-honed as phases shift. I can eat as much as a 200lb dude, so my journey is learning how to eat like a bird. Cheers!

top_comments.text:
One of the things we did was:
* realize that the four grams of carbohydrates we need daily is made by our liver. 
* realize that anything over that amount has to be either burned immediately or stored in a fat cell. 
* realize that 4 grams of carbohydrates equals an entire teaspoon of sugar. 
...Then we read labels and, in horror, simply threw out things in our pantry that we would never eat again. 
We immediately donated our toaster and our rice maker. That's the commitment you have got to do. Label reading and deciding. It's not easy, but it's the right thing and the right thing isn't always easy, but it's always right.

top_comments.text:
Main reasons imo why they fail is‚Ä¶ (btw saying this as 1 year strict carnivore, 1.5 normal carnivore (including dairy) and 3 years raw primal/raw carnivore prior to starting carnivore so not inexperienced in carnivore lifestyle) 

- Convenience (financial convenience, sourcing convenience eg. Fats, bone marrow, organs, grass fed/grass finished, social convenience, regional convenience eg. Going on holiday to a resort where meals are prepaid for and you can‚Äôt be completely carnivore. 

- Adaptation struggles in early phases. Stool movement problems, (Possibly Bile Acid Malabsorption, or most commonly not eating enough fat causing constipation.) heart palpitation from an energy prioritisation change (hearing beat in ear when sleeping, this passes after some time but the more you cheat and mess with carbs, the longer the process), possible tiredness from not utilising fat for energy as well in initial phases which gets better but don‚Äôt stop training (whether on carb or fat diet, people who train will know that when you stop, your endurance ends up dropping and so does strength. Understanding exercise timing is important. The meals in carnivore diets a larger and longer to digest meals usually so exercise feels best imo either in the morning before eating large meals or 5-6 hours after a large meal. It‚Äôs not that you won‚Äôt have energy but your body will be taxed more when trying to process a large meal and also being put through physically straining exercise at the same time . Little pro tip though, if you insist on eating before workout, eggs digest really fast compared to other carnivore foods. 27 mins for eggs to digest. I personally don‚Äôt really do little snack meals on carnivore usually but if you feel really hungry and sluggish to workout perhaps due to not fully adapting or maybe due to the last meal before being too long ago, eggs are amazing because they digest faster and satiating. 
Mineral/vitamin imbalances perhaps but I never had this for any other than vitamin D for which I was just told to take tablets for a bit then make sure once I get through the tablets to get enough sunlight. as someone who has bloodworks done like once a year, I didn‚Äôt have any other deficiencies in vitamins/minerals. 

- Locking yourself in mid dke of animal base/carnivore and constantly going in and out of keto so not feeling as good. 

-Overloading on caffeine. Yes you‚Äôre not having sugar and it‚Äôs still keto but it‚Äôs still not ideal and using coffee as a way of weight loss and ensuring stool movement is not the ideal way to do carnivore. In my opinion, it‚Äôs not even carnivore but it‚Äôs still animal based ketovore so still really good but if you overdo it, then you end up taking over certain stuff that switching to carnivore/keto should do anyway. And coffee still has oxalates so on a diet trying to lower antinutrients, drinking coffee isn‚Äôt ideal and I understand some people love their morning coffee but they‚Äôre not giving themselves the chance to experience how great it feels to be in ketosis and not need coffee to wake them up. And also, drinking coffee makes you not get hungry but you already shouldn‚Äôt be getting hungry anyway if you eat until you‚Äôre full on carnivore on fat and meat meals. You may not eat enough due to this and then yes you will lose weight but you‚Äôll lose it in a nutritionally deficient way, so not in a healthy manner. If you wanna lose weight and your eating as much as you want before full is too much for weight loss goals, then you can do so with different ratios of fat/protein. Increasing the fat ratio works for some because it‚Äôs calorically higher yes but practically it‚Äôs also more satiating and usually people can‚Äôt eat as much after. Plus adjusting training to match weight loss goals can help since weight isn‚Äôt just dietary. You can also implement raw meat/fat. I‚Äôve found that eating raw meat of same volume can keep me satiated for longer than cooked meat. However, with raw fat, although I feel more satiated, I can also eat way more raw fat in a sitting than cooked fat so that may change based on the person. 
There‚Äôs also different outcomes based on high meat but a carnivore beginner probably won‚Äôt need to concern themselves with high meat lol. 

I could probably come up with more but Im tired of writing.
top_comments.author: @denizkenger52
